reviewText: We have the first three movies and found this one to be just as wonderful.  I love these stories, I adore Chad Allen and the supporting characters seem to be more real, less stereotypical as they evolve through the series of movies.Although the office assistant character is less grating in this movie, he continues to be almost a caricature.  I am hoping by the next movie he comes into his own a little more.

reviewText: On this board, I have made no secret of my high regard for the "film noir" type" Donald Strachey detective films".  I simply adore the Donald Strachey mysteries along with the character of super-tough. detective (private investigator) Donald Strachey as marvelously played by Chad  Allen along with the character of  his life-partner (boyfriend) as wonderfully played by Sebastian Spence.  Their relationship, to me, is so marvelous being filled with lots of love, loyalty, and humor.  This fourth release of "Ice Blues" has been eagerly awaited by me and I am NOT disappointed.  "Ice Blues" is yet another very, very good Detective/mystery film. If anything, it's the very best so far and that is saying a lot because all have been fantastic.Indeed "Ice Blues" is a very riveting Detective/murder/mystery film on one (1) disc running 84 minutes.  The film finds Strachey and his partner, Tim Callahan along with Strachey's office manager(and would-be crime-solving partner), Kenney confronting some very unsavory characters  including crooked lewyers, dope dealers, child pornographers all willing to maim Strachey and Tim to get some money back that was given to Strachey's boyfriend Tim for a "good" cause.  Tim gets to "play" detective and as a result is in "mortal danger" with Don Strachey, of course, coming to his rescue in his usual very tough manner.  Yes, this film kept me well entertained with its fabulous "Peter Gunn" type soundtrack. Sepia-toned film color, shadowy filmed figures, wonderful direction and, most of all, great acting.  I am just glad that the "powers that be" finally released "Ice Blues" in this country because it entertained me greatly.  I loved this DVD.
summary: ABOUT TIME, "ICE BLUES" IS FINALLY RELEASED!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Ice Blues (2008). Rated "R". Running Time: One hour, 24 mins.Directed by Ron Oliver. Written by Richard Stevenson, Ron McGee.The forth and last movie in the "Donald Strachey Mysteries" series.Chad Allen returns as "Donald Strachey". Sebastian Spence, Daryl Shuttleworth, Nelson Wong and P. Lynn Johnson also return.Our gay Private Investigator Donald Strachey (Chad Allen) is all tied up hanging by the arms in a garage. A hood uses a tasar gun on him to shock him and make him answer. Frank Zaillian (Sebastien Roberts) intimidates him to answer the question of where the money is at.Then the movie takes us two days earlier.  Donald's boyfriend, Timothy, the Senator's aide, thinks it is time for Donald to quit being a Private Investigator and find a new line of work. Donald says, "Nah!", but he will try to make more days off for them to go on a tropical vacation. Timothy is worried about Donald on the job.Later that night, in the parking garage, an attorney (Jason Poulsen) comes up to Timothy unexpectedly to tell him he wants to donate $3 million to the Safe Zone Program, but the donor wants to be anonymous. Timothy explains to him they cannot accept that kind of money without knowing whom it is from. Suddenly, a hood on a motorcycle chases after the attorney, shoots at him and misses. The attorney leaps over the rail and falls. Then the hood goes after Timothy.Also in the cast: Sherry Miller, Joe Dall'Antonia.Contains male frontal nudity, brief female nudity.Filmed in Langley, British Columbia, Canada.In English only. 5.1 Surround, 2.0 Dolby Digital. Subtitles in English SDH.Originally broadcast on the here! network.Third Man Out(2005).Shock to the System: A Donald Strachey Mystery(2006).On the Other Hand, Death: A Donald Strachey Mystery(2008).Ice Blues (2008).Too bad they didn't make anymore of these tv-movies of the Donald Strachey Mysteries, there are more books in the series written by author, Richard Stevenson:Death Trick (1981).On the Other Hand, Death (1984).Ice Blues (1986).Third Man Out (1992).Shock to the System (1995).Chain of Fools (1996).Strachey's Folly (1998).Tongue-Tied: A Donald Strachey Mystery(2003).Death Vows (A Donald Strachey Mystery)(2008).The 38 Million Dollar Smile (A Donald Strachey Mystery)(2009).Cockeyed (A Donald Strachey Mystery)(2010).Red White Black and Blue (Donald Strachey Mystery)(2011).The Last Thing I Saw (Donald Strachey Mystery)(2012).
summary: Gay P.I. Donald Strachey is all tied up in this case.

reviewText: I LOVE the Donald Strachey series.  I'm not sure how many stories there are but I wish they'd make a movie out of all of them.  However, I feel that Chad Allen might be getting a little old to be believable as the detective who always seems to be getting beaten up or shot at or whatever.  But, I really enjoy the on-screen dynamic between Strachey and his partner Tim (Sebastian Spence).

reviewText: This is another Donals Strachey movie that follows along in the tradition of the previous ones.  Once again the two lead characters are so believeable it is hard to believe that the actor playing Timothy is not gay.  I recommend not only this movie but the series to all who like mysteries.  I purchase each one just as soon as they are released.

reviewText: Having fans wait 2 yrs. after the release of Donald Strachey's fourth mystery "Ice Blues" seems like a ridiculously long time. What was the delay?? Doesn't matter now. The good news is that it's finally being released on USA format soon.From what I've heard, detective Strachey (the terrific Chad Allen) & his partner Tim (the equally terrific Sebastian Spence) get in way over their heads on a high-profile case. Those who've seen it on Here! have said it's great. Can't wait to own it! : )
summary: Such a LONG wait; but another Strachey mystery is worth it!

reviewText: I have enjoyed all of the Donald Strachey movies, but this one was my favorite.  Waiting 2 years since it was shown on Here! TV was horrible.  I understand there were problems with the financial end for the producers in bringing the last film to DVD.  Whatever the reason, I can't wait for this to be delivered.  The casting of Chad Allen as the hard edged dectective with the loving side is absolutely perfect!

reviewText: Thank God for the Canadian Film Board because Hollywood rarely makes gay characters look respectful and ordinary.  Chad Allen and Sebastian Spence are a perfectly ordinary but good looking couple loaded with sex appeal and pizzaz.  I fell in love with mystery books and movies a few years ago because it feels so good to relate to gay heroes like Michael Nava's "Henry Rios", John Morgan Wilson's "Benjamin Justice" and Richard Stevenson's "Donald Strachey".Strachey, Nava and Justice are intelligent, courageous, sweet, tough, sexy and flawed.  What more could you ask for?I only wish here! had made more movies to view because I haven't found any more gay detectives on dvd. HEAR HERE!Oh, the jazzy soundtrack is kicking! thanks to music by Peter Allen and Vincent Mai.

reviewText: Chad Allen's "Don Strachey" is a breath of fresh air when it comes to gay films. A tough, masculine man, smart, wry and resourceful, nobody's fool, with a big heart, out and in love with his partner. Nothing cartoonish about him. He's got the Four Masculine Virtues down that make for a real man: strength, courage, competence and honor.Really, where else do you see anyone remotely like this kind of gay guy on screen?Part of the credit goes to Richard Stevenson's writing, and a lot of it goes to Allen himself, who is terrific. A real pleasure to watch.When it comes to plot and secondary characters, however, my enthusiasm slows. There's a repetitive quality to the situations in Stevenson's novels: victims, often young and gay, abused by powerful, often closeted and conservative, men. His latest book, "Red & White & Black & Blue" seems to be a reworking of the child-abusing bishop and the leathersex-loving closeted politico in "Third Man Out", with some drearily predictable gay histrionics about Tea Party politics added in. I'd say that Strachey-as-character is his great creation, while the narratives are not always up to par.
